titleStmt.title: A great and bloudy fight at Colchester, and the storming of the town by the Lord Generals forces, with the manner how they were repulsed and beaten off, and forced to retreat from the walls, and a great and terrible blow given at the said storm, by granadoes and gunpowder. Likewise their hanging out the flag of defiance, and their sallying out upon Tuesday last, all the chief officers ingaging in the said fight, and Sir Charles Lucas giving the first onset in the van, with the number killed and taken, and Sir Charles Lucas his declaration.

titleStmt.title: A great and bloudy fight at Colchester, and the storming of the town by the Lord Generals forces, with the manner how they were repulsed and beaten off, and forced to retreat from the walls, and a great and terrible blow given at the said storm, by granadoes and gunpowder. Likewise their hanging out the flag of defiance, and their sallying out upon Tuesday last, all the chief officers ingaging in the said fight, and Sir Charles Lucas giving the first onset in the van, with the number killed and taken, and Sir Charles Lucas his declaration.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A great and bloudy FIGHT AT COLCHESTER,

AND The Å¿torming of the Town by the Lord Generals Forces, with the manner how they were repulÅ¿ed and beaten off, and forced to retreat from the Walls, and a great and terrible blow given at the Å¿aid Å¿torm, by Granadoes and Gunpowder. LikewiÅ¿e their hanging out the Flag of Defiance, and their Å¿allying out upon TueÅ¿day laÅ¿t, all the chief Officers ingaging in the Å¿aid Fight, and Sir Charles Lucas giving the firÅ¿t onÅ¿et in the Van, with the number killed and taken, and Sir Charles Lucas his Declaration.
London Printed for G. Beal, and are to be Å¿old in the Old-Bayley, and neer Temple Bar, 1648.

div.head: A perfect RELATION Of the bloudy Å¿torming at COLCHESTER

div.p:
YEÅ¿terday being the 18. of this inÅ¿tant, about foure of the clock in the afternoon the great Guns from ColcheÅ¿ter plaid exceeding hard, both againÅ¿t our great Mount, and Å¿everall other Works and Fortifications. They killed one of our Gunners at the great Mount, 3 or 4 private Souldiers, and wounded Å¿ome few, and diÅ¿mounted one of our Pieces, and Å¿plit the muzzle; but we anÅ¿wered them again, and gave them three Å¿hots for one,
playing Å¿ixe pieces altogether for the Å¿pace of two houres againÅ¿t their Royall Fort and in the high Å¿treet.

Their chief Work which doth moÅ¿t annoy us, is their new Sconce which they have raiÅ¿ed oppoÅ¿ite to our great Mount, one ThompÅ¿on a Gunner Å¿upplying the Å¿ameâª who is an excellent Engineer, and an admirable marks man, and hath endangered two or three eminent Commanders; but one Mr. Smith, Gentleman of the Pikes to Col. Ewers Company, deÅ¿ired leave to make a Å¿hot againÅ¿t the Å¿aid Sconce, which accordingly was granten, and indeed it proved an excellent one; for he diÅ¿mounted one of their great braÅ¿Å¿e Pieces, & (its Å¿aid) wounded the Å¿aid ThompÅ¿on.

We have Å¿tormed one of their Å¿trongeÅ¿t Fortifications, neer the town, but before we could gain it, we had a hard diÅ¿putation, they knockt us off of our ladders, and threw down great Å¿tones and brick-bats upon us, and defended it with great reÅ¿olution; till at the laÅ¿t our men Å¿et to their ladders again, and up they went with great fury and reÅ¿olution, and got up to the Battlemens of the Gate-houÅ¿e, caÅ¿ting Granados out of their hands over amongÅ¿t the Souldiers, and one of the Å¿aid Granadoes falling into a roome where their Magazine lay, blew up divers barrels of powder, and about 60. Souldiers, giving a moÅ¿t great and terrible blow.

Whereupon the reÅ¿t of their men that defended the Å¿aid Fortification cryed out for quarter, but not above 12. men were left of 150. a very Å¿ad Å¿pectacle to behold. Some arms were taken, but moÅ¿t of them Å¿poyled with the blow.

This was a very conÅ¿iderable place, add advantagious to the Enemy, the loÅ¿Å¿e of which did infuÅ¿e a great deale of wrath and terrour in the heart of Sir Charles Lucas, and cauÅ¿ed him to make a deÅ¿perate Å¿alley out upon us, but were repulÅ¿ed and beaten in with loÅ¿Å¿e.

Whereupon he Å¿hot Å¿everall Granadoes out of the town and fired all the Subburbs, and upon Sunday and Munday laiÅ¿ â¢ plaid with his great Ordnance into the Leaguer, which did Å¿omewhat annoy us, and killed Å¿ome of our men, one having his leg Å¿hot off, another his skull broken, and Å¿ome others wounded.

They have Å¿everall advantages to play upon us, which doth embolden them the more, and upon TueÅ¿day morning laÅ¿t, before the Trevalle had beat, Sir Charles Lucas Å¿allyed out in perÅ¿on himÅ¿elf, together with Gen. HaÅ¿tings, Col. Lunsford, and divers other perÅ¿ons of quality, with about 400. HorÅ¿e, and 1000 Foot, and having notice of their comming, prepared to receive them, who upon their neer approach gave them Å¿uch a volley that they retreated, but immediatly rallied and came on again; inÅ¿omuch that there hapned a very Å¿hary diÅ¿pute betwixt both parties, and continued for the Å¿pace of a quarter of an hour, Sir Charles horÅ¿e was Å¿hot under him, and divers on both Å¿ides wounded; but they perceiving Col. Whaleyes comming up with his horÅ¿e, made good their retreat and got Å¿afe into the town, only they loÅ¿t about 20 men in this conflict.

We have finiÅ¿hed our Battery againÅ¿t St. Iohns, and have made a great breach in the town walls, notwithÅ¿tanding their WoolÅ¿acks, which our Souldiers fetcht away upon their backs, and beat them out of one Court yard into another, and out of the houÅ¿e into another great houÅ¿e, doing Å¿ome execution Å¿till in the purÅ¿uit.
Col. Whaley with his own horÅ¿e and the Suffolk Foot hath likewiÅ¿e given them another great blow, and hath taken two of their Courts of Guards and a Church, and above 100. priÅ¿oners.

YeÅ¿terday we received further intelligence, that Lieutenant
Generall Cromwel and his Forces advanced from Pembrook towards the North of England on Fryday laÅ¿t, and is reÅ¿olved to joyn with Major Generall Lambert, to hinder the Scots marching Southward, and to fight with them; for we are credibly informed, that they have entred England, & with a very conÅ¿iderable Army, are come on this Å¿ide of CarliÅ¿le.

we are advertized, that about 1500. men lookt upon the EngliÅ¿h Å¿hore to relieve Sandon and Deal CaÅ¿tles in Kent, but finding our Forces readier then they expected to ingage with them, they packt aboard again, and are gone to Sea. It is thought they will Å¿trike in again at Å¿ome other place; and to prevent their landing on EÅ¿Å¿ex Å¿ide, the L. Gen. hath Å¿ent a Å¿trong party to Harwich, and hath given notice to Norwich and Yarmouth, his Forces are even under the walls on all Å¿ides of ColcheÅ¿ter, and makes preparations as if he intended to Å¿torm the town,

div.head: A briefe AbÅ¿tract of Å¿everall Lettees from the North.
div.p: By letters from the North it is certified, That on TueÅ¿day laÅ¿t Sir Marm. Langdale joyned with the Scots Army, they make about 12000 HorÅ¿e and Foot; Maj. Gen. Lambert hath Å¿ent into YorkÅ¿hire and LincolnÅ¿hire for more Forces, that he may fight them his Army is already conÅ¿iderable, and may fight them without diÅ¿advantage nothing yet of action; before next PoÅ¿t day we may heare much from thence.
The Scots poÅ¿Å¿ â¢ Å¿Å¿e Barwick, TueÅ¿day next Col. LeÅ¿ley Nephew to Gen. LeÅ¿ley, is to be Governour.

The HouÅ¿e receiving Letters from Major Gen. Lambert, Å¿ignifying that an Army of Scots were come into this Kingdome, under the command of D. Hambleton, the Commons declared thoÅ¿e forces which in a hoÅ¿tile manner have entred this Kingdome to be Enemies, and that all perÅ¿ons which adhere unto them either of this Kingdom or of Ireland, are traytors and Rebels.

They debate concerning the place for the Treaty, whether at London, or ten miles diÅ¿tant, London not by any meanes thought Å¿ecure, the inconveniencies being numerous, and therefore came to this ReÅ¿olution.

p.q: That after the three propoÅ¿itions be conÅ¿ented unto, and Å¿igned, as is deÅ¿ired, the King Å¿hould be deÅ¿ired to name three places within 20 miles of Westminster, two of which to be at leaÅ¿t ten miles diÅ¿tant from WeÅ¿tminster, where the Treaty Å¿hall be, and then both HouÅ¿es of Parliament Å¿hall have liberty to make choice of one of them as they Å¿hall think fit.

div.p: Letters from Hull Å¿ay, that a Man of War rid neer that Towne, Å¿ome Å¿hips went forth to diÅ¿cover what Å¿he was they found her to be a Hollander laden with Ammunition, and good Å¿tore of HorÅ¿e Arms, the MaÅ¿ter of the Å¿hip Å¿ai â¢ h, that they were deÅ¿igned to a Gentleman of LincolnÅ¿hire, which had formerly Å¿erved the King, whereupon the Governour Col. Overton Å¿ent out a party of HorÅ¿e which brought the Gentleman into Hull.

The laÅ¿t night the troops of Col. Rich his men, and thoÅ¿e of com-Gen. Iretons Regiment which have bin in purÅ¿uit of the D. of Buckinghams party returned back again and ferried over at Putney into Surrey, and are deÅ¿igned again into Kent, he feares increaÅ¿ing in that county by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome Å¿hips which are Å¿aid to be comming thither out of Holland, with whom, the report goes, is the Duke of Yo â¢ k or the Prine, but its rather believed (if there be either) that it is the Duke, becauÅ¿e Å¿ome letters Å¿ay, that he was entertained a board a little before the Prince his comming into Holland.

There was a Gentleman taken at Rumford upon Å¿uÅ¿pirion, and in his portmantell was found many CommiÅ¿Å¿ions for Prince Charles to Å¿ign and Å¿eale, and other papers of great concernment, he was brought to London, his perÅ¿on Å¿ecured, and the papers referred to the Committee at Derby houÅ¿e.

By Letters out of Kent it is advertized, that the Forces under command of CommiÅ¿Å¿ary Gen. Ireton, and Collonell Rich are in a poÅ¿ture to receive the Duke of Yorkes Forces, if they land, and are very vigilant to attend the motion of them.

The KentiÅ¿h-men have declared their reÅ¿olution to aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t them, proteÅ¿ting to hazard lives and fortunes for the preÅ¿ervation of the peace of their native Country, againÅ¿t all force or power either forreign or domeÅ¿tique.

It is further advertized from Colchester, that the beÅ¿ieged having received intelligence of the Duke of Yorks comming to the Downs, are grown very obÅ¿tinate and reÅ¿olute & have Å¿et forth a flag of Defiance, and refuÅ¿eth to hearken to a Å¿urrender, notwithÅ¿tanding the late Å¿ummons, and fair promiÅ¿es of the Lord Generall. Sir Charles Lucus tels the Å¿ouldiers, that he hath received a meÅ¿Å¿age from the Duke of Yorke, and declares, that his HighneÅ¿Å¿e will Å¿end relief to them before Friday night.
